rComments: Raoul is a very good, interesting teacher who is very knowledgeable about the world of Buddhism. However,  his grading policies are extremely unfair. He says he doesn't believe in grades, so he withholds all the grades he gives you on the papers you write, so you don't know how you're doing in class. Then at the end he gives badgrades w no warning.

This professor is very knowledgeable! He speaks with clarity, especially in a small seminar. Attending his class feels like home because he makes you think in a way you've never had before. He talks from a Buddhist point of view, but he also respects your thoughts. I've had a great learning experience in his class.

I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in learning about Buddhist culture and philosophy.  If you aren't interested in Buddhism, you'll hate it.  I appreciated that the proff had a lot of relevant stories from his own life.  The class lacks a rigid structure so if you're not comfortable taking initiative it could be frustrating.

His Buddhism classes aren't about art, but he says that on the first day and in the syllabus. No paper prompts, which actually force you to think (blasphemy!!). Does talk about his experiences, but not in a conceited way. He lived in monasteries for years, which is highly relavant to the material. Expect to be challenged in new ways.

Honestly, he seems very self important. It shouldn't be listed as a HAVC class.I was interested in learning more about Buddhism. This was disappointing as well. It seems he just wanted a class where he could talk about himself. Also, he gives no indication of how you're doing during the class and that is very frustrating. I wouldn't recommend him.

You basically just sit there and listen to him talk about himself and his life. Honestly, I think he's a bit of a snob or should I say an elitest hippy. There's no paper prompts, but he expects a lot from you. It's hard to learn from his way of lecturing and the textbooks are just compilation of short stories. Not a art history class AT ALL.

Excellent class, knowledgeable professor. Don't expect an art class from BVW, he explains on the first day the class will be about Buddhism. Don't expect easy concepts to grasp... Do expect to learn something useful for life.

I was very enthusiastic about this course prior to taking it, but I found professor Birnbaum highly unacademic. He is very kind but don't take this class if your aim is to gain knowledge and train your critical skills! Everything is VERY loose and there are no paper prompts. It's a HAVC course but there is unfortunately NO focus on visual culture!

Great instructor on Buddhism and Idealisms. T.A. was a bit slow, and had a stuttering problem. The course topic was excellent and very interesting, if you have taken Power and Presence in Asia (Havc 10D) it will give you more of an advantage, but the early sections of the course can be a little "deja-vu" for the most part. Recommended class though.

The prompts for each essay were very unclear. He goes on tangents. I don't feel that I have gained any knowledge about Chinese religions. Instead of teaching, he reflected on his past experiences. He talks very slowly. Overall, the class was okay. I should have received an A.

If you like to write essays with no prompts and have the a Professor force his religious opinions on you, definetely take this class. You will probably get a bad grade, sit through boring lectures, and develop a passive agressive frustration for the horrible teaching and grading methods of Professor Birnbaum if you take one of his classes.

Not an art history class so much as an intro to Buddhist studies/themes/spirituality. What an interesting man...he is so knowledgeable and has lived in Chinese monasteries and is fluent. Well known and respected in academia too.Be prepared to like about 1/4 of the readings and slog thru the rest. Great teacher, boring texts.

He is very nice and can be helpful, but the class focuses very little on the visual or cultural aspect of Buddhist art. It is more a narrative history of Buddhist thought. To compound this, there is a paper due every other week for which there is little to no guidance. The papers are difficult solely because they are completely without directions.

I'd agree with most everything already posted. Not enough comment on the visual or artistic aspect the work in question. Should be called, "Buddhist Worlds." He admits as much up front at the beginning of class though, so no one should be fooled.

Birnbaum is good.  There are no surprises in his class - the work load is exactly what he says it is.  The only slight problem with him is that he talks very little of the visual aspect of Buddhism in the class.  He gives an intro of buddhism.  And ive been in classes where students THOUGHT they knew everything-and were POLITELY put in their place
Very good professor that speaks very percise. he talkes as if he knows what he is talking about, unlike a lot of teachers. The work load is not bad either.
Very mellow, clear thinker...a very pleasant class.  Lot's of papers replace exams (no midterm, quizzes or final!!!!).  I recommend this class (satisfies 3 GEs) and I recomment Prof. Birnbaum.
